BE11:15am

Oil jumped following the shooting down by Iran of a US drone which the US said was in international airspace but which Iran claimed had
violated its airspace. President Trump had tweeted that ‘Iran made a very big mistake!’ but subsequently suggested that the action may have
been unintentional amidst reports that the administration had pulled back from launching retaliatory strikes on Iranian military positions.
The risk that the US might find itself at war with Iran caused Democratic party leaders to insist that Congress would need to be involved in
any decision to take action against Iran.
Likely Iranian military action against vessels and US military assets is certainly ramping up the risk of US military retaliation and the vacillation
of the US stance by a President who is seen as both capricious but broadly unwilling to commit US military assets in a hot conflict may well
see Iran taking additional action to test US resolve. However, in the end, the conventional military capability of the US far outweighs that of
Iran. Until it becomes clearer when this current phase of escalation is topping out, military threat is likely to continue to be an important
factor driving global crude prices.
Injections of natural gas into US storage totalled 115bcf for the week to 14 June, notably above market estimates of a 106bcf build and
continuing the trend of above average refills; the five-year average build for this time of the year is 84bcf. For the YtD, injections are running
at 39% above average. Gas in storage amounts to 2,203bcf, with the deficit to the five-year average down to just 8%. That pace of refill
continued to pressure US and, given the linkage via LNG, European gas prices.

JP11:17am

Yeah, that seems to be the gist of a UBS report on Gold this AM:

JP11:17am

Policy easing is positive for goldGold is being increasingly viewed as a strategic asset to hold against the backdrop of uncertainty – lower real rates in the US and globally makes gold more attractive. Gold has been supported of late by the decline in rates and increasingly dovish Fed expectations. The latest FOMC meeting delivered a dovish outcome that has vindicated the market to an extent, allowing gold to jump to the highest levels since prices collapsed in 2013. Gold rallied over 3% from where it was trading just before the FOMC. Many market participants had missed the move through $1300 and have been waiting for a dip to jump in. The extension of gold's rally after a brief pause around $1350 could be intensifying the market's 'fear of missing out'.

11:17 am
JP11:17am

Positioning could still act as a drag near term, but there's room to grow overallSpeculative positions increased over 12moz in the last three weeks to June 11, and Comex gold futures open interest was up another 3moz to Tuesday this week. Gold ETFs are up 1.95moz so far this month. With the G20 meeting still ahead, some positive developments could trigger unwinding of these positions in the near-term, especially given how far gold has moved. That said, market participants are likely to view any consolidation as an opportunity to build positions. More broadly, we think exposure to gold remains relatively lean and there should be scope for further gains in positioning ahead.

JP11:17am

Resilience to a stronger dollar and equities is likelyThe current macro backdrop of declining real rates and lingering uncertainty should help gold stay resilient in the face of a potential rebound in the dollar and further gains in equities. Trade and geopolitical risks are fluid and tend to have a volatile impact on gold prices, but the general unease this creates among market participants helps reinforce gold's role as a safe haven. Policy easing and the compression in real rates would have a more sustained positive impact on gold.

BE11:21am

The Fed delivered on Wed, essentially providing "insurance" (link) amid an uncertain
backdrop, and UBS econ now sees a 50bp cut in July (link). Using our S&P P/E model,
the fall in US rates since March would have boosted the multiple by over 0.4x. Indeed,
US valuations have moved back toward the highs of last fall, suggesting lower rates are
priced. Thus, the backdrop for risk assets will be driven by growth developments, with
the G20 potentially another key fulcrum. Within equities, stocks that benefit most from
lower rates (defensives, growth) are trading at a record 120% P/E premium to stocks
hurt most by lower rates (financials, cyclicals). Accordingly, a neutral/positive G20
outcome could see that extreme premium for rate sensitivity compress some.

BE11:21am

Tariff exposed stocks and stocks with the highest China sales exposure have retraced
30-40% of the relative underperformance of May. Using our proprietary mapping of
tariff codes to NAICS industries to companies, we group stocks in the industries most
impacted by tariffs into the 3 tranches (i.e. $50bn, $200bn, $300bn threat). Stocks in
tranches 1 and 2 saw relative valuations fall 10% near peak points of escalation in the
spring and Q4. Median relative P/Es in tranche 2 are still 10% lower. On the other
hand, stocks in tranche 3 de-rated in May but have retraced all of that discount. Thus,
we like being long stocks in tranche 2 over those in tranche 3, for mostly any outcome.

Irish HF guy @Excel, https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/T5YIFR
Excel Developer @BE,@JP: oil, gold, macro, you are really spoiling us (me) today!
red but underlined if data demands it, they will. otherwise mkt will be in for a surprise
BE11:22am

Global equity P/Es have tracked global growth and are pricing the mild H1 recovery but
not a further turn up in H2, and certainly not the hit to growth on further tariffs. UBS
econ sees talks resuming in their baseline, with still elevated risks, and the path to some
sort of deal to ward off escalation (link). We had estimated a ~7% EPS hit on the 75-
100bp hit to US GDP growth on a further tariff scenario (link). In our Q-series, we
found that US and Chinese assets had the greatest discount from trade and would
stand to benefit the most on resolution. German and Taiwan equities stood out as
attractive hedges for further escalation, while Materials is most at risk to trade/cycle.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

With global mfg PMIs hovering above 50, a turn up in the cycle would likely lead to a
rotation from low vol/defensives to value/cyclicals. A Fed cut in July could be a further
boost if the expansion is sustained and median cycle timing points to a global PMI
trough around July as well. Relative valuations of low vs high beta and high vs low price
momentum stocks are in the

98th pctl, suggesting the rotation risk is notable (link).

Across sectors, this would favor the likes of Energy over Utilities, and EM across regions
tactically. On a further slowdown, cyclicals would continue to get hurt, in line with UBS
US equity strategists' views. But we believe high momentum growth stocks with low
FCF yields would also be at risk. Stocks with the highest sales growth and lowest FCF
yields have been among the worst performers at the last stages of a cycle when PMIs
keep falling.

BE11:22am

Our composite measure shows that equity positioning is 1.2stdev below avg, and down
notably from early May levels and slightly above YTD lows. Thus, a Fed cut, an ok G20
outcome and decent data could see risk exposures increased. The very large bond rally
means that the implied equity allocation is still ~3pp below last year's highs despite
equities rallying in 2019. Lastly, nearly $600bn has gone into money market funds the
last 2yrs with most in the last year; so cash can still return to risk markets.

JP11:22am

And to finish on the topic of the Fed, Morgan Stanley weighs in:

red nfps in a couple of wks and gdp will be key. any upside there and boom goes 100% july price in
11:22 am
JP11:22am

Expecting a Fed cut and curve steepening: Our US economists now expect the Federal Reserve to cut by 50bp at its next meeting, on July 31. Our US rates strategists expect both the 2s10s and 2s30s curve to steepen further.

Bull steepening and Fed cuts go together: The yield curve can be in one of four phases (rising/falling, steepening/flattening). Fed cuts usually mean bull steepening, although we look at returns in all four phases.

Cross-asset performance after the first cut: Historically, following the first Fed cut, the USD weakens, equity returns are below average, US Treasuries do well, and credit does poorly. There is an understandable bi-modal distribution here, with the "first cut" experience looking much different in '01 and '08 versus '95 and '98.

Excel Developer @Irish HF guy: wow, totally brilliant , thanks very much. I look at FRED often , it never occurred to me they have the data series. Thanks again.
JP11:22am

Cross-asset performance during steepening: Bull steepening has tended to see below-average equity returns, outperformance by both defensive stocks, dollar weakness (vs. G10), higher prices for oil and gold, US Treasury strength, and wider credit spreads. Bear steepening has tended to see much stronger risk asset returns, in part because it often occurs "early cycle".

Where are the disconnects?: Relative to historical periods of bull steepening, US credit, technology stocks, and the US dollar have not only outperformed recently, but have moved in the opposite direction one would have expected. In contrast, Healthcare and Energy stocks, the euro, copper and oil have historically done well during bull steepening, yet have recently underperformed.

Spectare Forward money market rates have been signalling a cut for months. The Fed is really the central bank to the world. If they dont cut to bale out the eurodollar market the dollar will fly, increasing deflationary pressure and futherb blowing up their tired phillips curve model of employment vs price. Basically the have lost the plot and need to catch up

TrustMyUnit Anyone excited about Trainline?
BE11:28am

IQE had initially taken a cautiously optimistic take on the impact to it of Huawei being added to the U.S. Department of Commerce’s Entity List, when in late May it estimated less than 5% of its 2019 sales to be at risk. This morning, it has provided further detail and materially cut its 2019 sales guidance by 3x this level to around 15% at the midpoint. They now see sales of £140-160m, a decline of 5% y/y at the midpoint and below our recently reduced £163m and materially below consensus £175m, driven primarily by the impact of the Huawei ban which is resulting in forecast cuts from a number of its customers primarily in Wireless (RF) but also Photonics (Datacom/optical) segments. It also highlights a separate customer-specific issue in the datacom/optical segment.

11:29 am
JP11:29am

As a result, IQE now expects growth of 30% in Photonics vs. prior greater than 50% and for Wireless to decline by 20-25% vs. prior 15%. Our prior estimates called for 52% growth in Photonics and -19% decline in Wireless, the latter where we had tried to take account of the Huawei impact. In sum, IQE has cut the midpoint of its 2019 guidance to 15% below prior consensus and has also reduced its operating profit margin to “significantly below” the prior greater than 10% guidance. It is taking action to reduce cost and capex, but its cost base is largely fixed in the near-term.

Irish HF guy Trainline has a 5x value to GOGO and does not make as much money!
BE11:29am

As a result, IQE now expects growth of less than 30% in Photonics vs. prior greatger than 50% and for Wireless to decline by 20-25% vs. prior 15%. Our prior estimates called for 52% growth in Photonics and -19% decline in Wireless, the latter where we had tried to take account of the Huawei impact. In sum, IQE has cut the midpoint of its 2019 guidance to 15% below prior consensus and has also reduced its operating profit margin to “significantly below” the prior greater than 10% guidance. It is taking action to reduce cost and capex, but its cost base is largely fixed in the near-term.

Irish HF guy GOCO apologies!
FATDAZ @excel use the format button to ploy different series on a different access and adjust the periodicity of the the plots to get best result ie weekly ending Friday, monthly, quarterly etc
BE11:30am

The semiconductor industry is operating in challenging circumstances given the uncertainty generated by the U.S.-China trade war and specifically the U.S. actions against Huawei. We did not expect IQE to be immune from this and had attempted to factor in the impact, but given IQE’s position deeper in the foodchain, this has been greater than we anticipated. Relative to the rest of the industry, this is the biggest cut we have seen to date across global semiconductors. We continue to like IQE’s long-term position as a supplier of highly differentiated product into the structurally growing compound semiconductor industry, but the near-term negative impact is now clearly greater and IQE’s visibility less. Our rating is Overweight with an 80p price target.

JP11:31am

IQE warns that trade war is beginning to bite hard
IQE expects to report £65-68m revenue for 1H19, which at midpoint will have been 39% of our prior FY19E revenue forecast,
and broadly in line with the 40:60 seasonality guidance from
March. That said, the global outlook for the industry has
materially changed since then. While medium-to-longer-term
structural growth drivers remain unchanged, the global semis
supply chains will now need to rethink their structure for a brave
new world. So, despite IQE seeing the Photonics ramp in May
and June, it is now flagging materially subdued demand for both
the Wireless (Power Amplifier products) and the Photonics
divisions, the latter driven mostly by a customer-specific
weakness in fibre laser products. The Infrared division, which
mainly targets the western defence markets, remains unaffected.
With the global handset growth now at risk, and the
infrastructure growth hampered by supply chain complications,
we move our FY19E revenue forecast to £146.7m (vs £172.2m
previously and IQE’s new guide of £140-160m) and adj
operating margin forecast to 5.1% (vs 10.0% previously). This
moves our FY18-21E cc revenue CAGR from 17% to 13%,
resulting in a FY19E adjusted EPS cut of 53%. We think the YE
net debt position will be c£15m, which will be absorbed by the
$35m RCF facility. The EPS cut moves our PT to 108p, which
is based on the top end of the longer-term sector average P/E.

red with no end to trade war in sight, nor for huawei, brave call to buy...
11:31 am
BE11:32am

It is, I suggest, extremely brave to consider IQE as a lead indicator for the semi sector given the number of questions about its quality of earnings etc.

JP11:32am

Not wholly surprising. Back in May, IQE quantified the Huawei exposure and left FY19E guidance unchanged. Last week, we flagged the big warning by industry bellwether Broadcom, where “uncertainty [about] the environment has put in place a concern about placing additional orders and [has resulted in an active] reduction of inventory.” We are now starting to see the wider
repercussions of the trade war, with the hope for a 2H19 recovery being dashed for the sector as a whole. The weak announcements from Qorvo, Skyworks, Cree, Inphi, Lumentum and NeoPhotonics are beginning to look like just teasers.

BE11:32am

As summarised here: https://ftalphavil...Cardiff-chip-shop/

FATDAZ @BE semiconductors were being touted as as key barometer of global growth / trade outlook a few weeks back will rate cuts ride to their rescue as well I wonder?
anonymous254 How does Trainline make money? Is it just by charging a booking fee vs. going direct to operator website?
11:32 am
JP11:33am

Some green shoots. We have in the past talked about IQE’s heightened strategic attraction given the ongoing trade war. With a globally-spread manufacturing capability, and a significant chunk of that sitting outside the US, IQE is well placed to offer component manufacturers (and OEMs) alternative supply chain paths. Its well flagged Taiwan (flagship wireless EpiFoundry, plus Photonics, NIL) expansion, for example, will become even more strategic. The company also continues to guide for two further customers entering VCSEL massproduction in H2 at the Newport foundry, with another 13 undergoing qualification. It also hopes for some of the 5G-related fibre laser demand (in Photonics) to pick-up in Q4 with new customers, potentially compensating for its struggling dominant customer. The trade-war is also creating new winners, and in the Wireless division IQE is already engaged with two such players. That said, we should remain mindful that the current semis environment is unprecedented given the decades it has taken to build the current global structure of the semis supply chain.

BE11:33am

You also have to consider why management was optimistic rather than pragmatic in the face of uncertainty that's halved its EPS expectation within a month.

Ole hand Trainline probably also gets their tickets on wholesale terms.
red @FATDAZnot sure rate cuts help in a trade war.

Yeah do read Dan's piece ROTR, excellent work from Derr Crummie Crum.

red @BE share options?
BE11:33am

Our prior estimates expected a return to ~25% yoy revenue growth in 2H, driven by the
strong ramp in Photonics revenues and slowing declines in wireless. At the midpoint of
management's new 2019 guidance range, 2H revenues would be broadly flat yoy, while
implied growth would be 11% yoy at the high end with a 10% decline at the low end.

BE11:34am

The demand recovery was building up nicely up until the Huawei ban caused additional
demand uncertainty and disruption in the supply chain. We admit investors' patience
and tolerance for earnings downgrades is tested yet again and at the demand lows it can
be tempting to 'throw in the towel'. Yet we have seen a few semiconductor cycles before
and believe the current weakness will not persist forever with a cyclical rebound only a
question of time. Add in the pending arrival of 5G and increasing evidence of adoption
of 3D sensing among Android OEM's, and we we have little doubt that IQE will eventually
return to its structural ~20% revenue and 50+% EPS trajectory.

Our EPS reductions and recent de-rating of semiconductor and supply chain peers
lead us to lower our target from 130p to 85p. This remains based on a blend of three
valuation approaches - a 20% premium to listed peers on a 2020 adj. P/E basis, historic
compound Semi M&A multiples and a 2022 bull case scenario that assumes a 2019-22
Photonics CAGR of 40% and 20% for wireless. Maintain BUY.

BE11:40am

What appeared to be green shoots in insurance pricing in 3Q and 4Q appears
to have reversed in 1H19. We believe GOCO, with its strategy of not spending
in a down cycle, should be disproportionately affected. GOCO reduced
marketing spend by ~13% in 2018 alongside slower growth. We expect
extended weakness in 1H19.
 The reverse should also be true in an upturn. GOCO has invested
aggressively in up-cycles such as 2016 when it increased marketing spend by
17%. New market opportunities may also lead GOCO to increase spending.
For example, in its CMD GOCO discussed the opportunity to work more
closely with insurers to provide more precisely targeted pricing and more
suitable coverage for consumers. We expect a recovery in 2H19.

BE11:41am

While the traditional business continues to be affected by the insurance cycle,
we remain optimistic on the long-term prospects for weflip. Automated
switching provides a compelling proposition to consumers and we like GOCO’s
targeting of infrequent rather than pro switchers that are not concerned about
attaining the best possible deal at all times. We estimate weflip grows
revenues to £19m and breaks even in 2021.

JP11:41am

SOTP is always tricky, because it ignores how the businesses within a larger company depend on each other.

The US customer has informed Nanoco that it will not be progressing with the application for which Nanoco was producing nanomaterials. Clearly, this is a major blow to the company’s prospects given that this was expected to move towards commercialisation in the short term. The company will explore opportunities to use the technology with other customers and continues to work on opportunities in other sectors. Nanoco expects to have a cash balance of c£6m at December 2019, based on a cash breakeven position for the calendar year, and will look to reduce cash burn. The business also has considerable IP, which will be of value to a third party. Given the lack of visibility of revenue and cashflow post the current year, we withdraw our recommendation and forecasts.

JP11:56am

Reiterate Outperform rating and raising price target to $355. We like the set-up for the balance of the year, as we think expectations have overshot to the negative and we believe there are several catalysts upcoming which could drive shares higher (beginning with the upcoming delivery release). Additionally, we have noticed bear arguments have preemptively shifted from demand to profitability. A solid Q2 delivery announcement could set up a positive cash flow quarter and set the stage for share appreciation in 2H:19.

JP11:56am

We expect TSLA will release Q2 delivery numbers on or before Wednesday, July 3, and think the stock should react positively, particularly given low expectations. For Q1, we model 18k Model S+X deliveries and 72.5k Model 3, vs. FactSet consensus of 16.6k/74.5k. There have been several positive data points over the course of the quarter; TSLA reiterated Q2 guidance on its capital raise in May, and Musk indicated TSLA could achieve record deliveries at the June analyst day (corroborated by leaked emails). The previous delivery record was 90.7k deliveries in Q4:18, guidance is 90k-100k deliveries for Q2. All in all, we think TSLA may be able to exceed lowered expectations, which would be positive for the stock.

11:56 am
JP11:56am

Estimates have overshot to the negative, in our view, and we think there are several catalysts over the next few months which could drive shares higher. Other than the delivery release, potentially positive upcoming catalysts include: 1) potential cash flow positive quarter, 2) Battery and Powertrain Analyst Day (expected this summer), 3) volume production from the Shanghai factory, 4) pickup truck unveiling, and 5) announcements regarding strategies to expand manufacturing/battery production capacity. Additionally, we note short interest remains extremely high (~44M shares, according to FactSet) and believe covering could provide an incremental buyer.

JP11:56am

Deliveries will likely be the central focus, though we do think investors will continue to monitor Model 3 production rates. We will look for an update on sustainable production levels, and potentially details on a path to increasing production, which we think would be positive for the stock.

JP11:56am

The Q2 delivery release could be one step in refuting the (unsubstantiated) bear argument that demand for the Model 3 has softened. We think any update on Model 3 demand/backlog would be positive for the stock, though TSLA has maintained there is no issue with demand. We think there is a chance TSLA could provide an updated demand outlook or data on trade-ins (similar to the annual shareholder meeting) which we think could help improve sentiment and additional details on the Q2 conference call should further disprove these concerns.

11:57 am
JP11:57am

I think it is worth pointing out that while Q2 will be okay -- I expect deliveries to be near 90k personally -- what happens in H2 is what matters.
